title: The Court Got It Right on Tariff Authority
author: Ed Whelan

claims.claim: The statutory holding correctly limits executive tariff authority to parameters Congress explicitly set.
Congress's delegation under IEEPA was never intended to authorize broad trade policy restructuring.
The major questions doctrine properly constrains agencies from claiming vast authority from ambiguous grants.

anchors.quote: Congress does not hide elephants in mouseholes
anchors.note: Standard major questions framing adopted from Whitman v. ATA

assumptions: Congressional delegation frameworks should be interpreted narrowly
The executive branch has historically overstepped on trade authority
Judicial review of executive trade actions is constitutionally necessary
tensions_or_flags: Treats the plurality major questions reasoning as if it were a holding
Does not address the dissent's historical delegation evidence
questions_for_cross_analysis: Does the statutory text of IEEPA actually limit tariff authority as claimed?
Which justices explicitly reject the major questions framing?
